Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structure and elements of literature.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structures and elements of literature.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structures and elements of literature.
Demonstrate understanding of print concepts.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.

Identify, analyze and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.
Identify, analyze and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.
Demonstrate understanding of print concepts.

Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the purpose, structures, and elements of expository text.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structure and elements of literature.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structures and elements of literature.
Identify, analyze, and apply knowledge of the structures and elements of literature.

Employ strategies to comprehend text.

Decode words, using knowledge of phonics, syllabication, and word parts.
Explain basic elements of argument in text and their relationship to the author's purpose and use of persuasive strategies.
Explain basic elements of argument in text and their relationship to the author's purpose and use of persuasive strategies.
Decode words, using knowledge of phonics, syllabication, and word parts.
Employ strategies to comprehend text.
Explain basic elements of argument in text and their relationship to the author's purpose and use of persuasive strategies.
Explain basic elements of argument in text and their relationship to the author's purpose and use of persuasive strategies.

Employ strategies to comprehend text.
Read fluently.
Employ strategies to comprehend text.
PO 1. Identify the purpose for reading expository text.
PO 1. Describe the historical and cultural aspects found in cross-cultural works of literature.
PO 1. Use knowledge of root words and affixes to determine the meaning of unknown words.
PO 1. Distinguish fact from opinion in persuasive text (e.g., advertisements, product labels, written communications).

PO 1. Evaluate the author's use of literary elements:
  • theme (moral, lesson, meaning, message, view or comment on life),
  • point of view (e.g., first vs. third, limited vs. omniscient),
  • characterization (qualities, motives, actions, thoughts, dialogue, development, interactions),
  • setting (time of day or year, historical period, place, situation), and
  • plot (exposition, major and minor conflicts, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution).
PO 1. Read from familiar prose and poetry with fluency and appropriate rhythm, pacing, intonation, and expression relevant to the text.
PO 1. Predict text content using prior knowledge and text features (e.g., illustrations, titles, topic sentences, key words).
PO 1. Synthesize information from multiple sources (e.g., texts, maps, illustrations, workplace documents, and schematic diagrams) to solve a problem.
PO 1. Critique the consistency and clarity of the text's purposes.
PO 1. Predict text content using prior knowledge and text features (e.g., illustrations, titles, topic sentences, key words).
PO 1. Read from a variety of genres with accuracy, automaticity (immediate recognition), and prosody (expression).
PO 1. Determine the effect of affixes on root words.
PO 1. Use information from text and text features to determine the sequence of activities needed to carry out a procedure.

PO 1. Describe the author's use of literary elements:
  • theme (moral, lesson, meaning, message, view or comment on life),
  • point of view (e.g., first vs. third, limited vs. omniscient),
  • characterization (qualities, motives, actions, thoughts, dialogue, development, interactions),
  • setting (time of day or year, historical period, place, situation), and
  • plot (exposition, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution).
PO 1. Make predictions based on title, cover, illustrations, and text.
PO 1. Describe the plot and its components (e.g., main events, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution).
PO 1. Determine what words mean from how they are used in a sentence, heard or read.
PO 1. Follow a set of written multi-step directions with picture cues to assist.
PO 1. Describe the historical and cultural aspects found in cross-cultural works of literature.
PO 1. Compare events, characters and conflicts in literary selections from a variety of cultures to their experiences.
PO 1. Draw inferences about meaning of new vocabulary, based on knowledge of linguistic roots and affixes (e.g., Latin, Greek, Anglo-Saxon).

PO 1. Decode regularly spelled two-syllable words fluently by applying the most common letter-sound correspondences, including the sounds represented by:
  • Single letters (consonants and vowels),
  • Consonant blends (e.g., bl, st, tr),
  • Consonant digraphs (e.g., th, sh, ck), and
  • Vowel digraphs and diphthongs (e.g., ea, ie, ee).
PO 1. Recognize that print represents spoken language and conveys meaning (e.g., his/her own name, Exit and Danger signs).
PO 1. Compare (and contrast) original text to a summary for accuracy of the main ideas, inclusion of critical details, and the extent to which it conveys the underlying meaning of the original text.
PO 1. Identify the central argument and its elements (e.g., argument by cause and effect, analogy, authority, emotion, or logic) in persuasive text.
PO 1. Recognize base words and their inflections (e.g., look, looks, looked, looking).
PO 1. Analyze the structures of functional text (e.g., their format, graphics and headers) to determine how authors use these features to achieve their purposes.
PO 1. Identify letters of the alphabet (upper and lower case).
PO 1. Restate the main idea (explicit or implicit) and supporting details in expository text.
PO 1. Read from a variety of genres with accuracy, automaticity (immediate recognition), and prosody (expression).
PO 1. Participate (e.g., react, speculate, join in, read along) when predictably patterned selections of fiction and poetry are read aloud.
PO 1. Identify the main problem or conflict of a plot.
PO 1. Predict what might happen next in a reading selection.
PO 1. Determine the meaning of vocabulary, using linguistic roots and affixes (e.g., Latin, Greek, Anglo-Saxon).
PO 1. Identify the main idea and supporting details in expository text.
PO 1. Determine the author's position regarding a particular idea, subject, concept, or object.
PO 1. Sequentially follow a two- or three-step set of directions (e.g., recipes, center directions, classroom procedures, science experiments) using picture clues.
PO 1. Predict text content using prior knowledge and text features (e.g., illustrations, titles, topic sentences, key words).
PO 1. Distinguish spoken rhyming words from non-rhyming words (e.g., run, sun versus run, man).
PO 1. Describe the historical and cultural aspects found in cross-cultural works of literature.
PO 1. Identify the plot of a literary selection, heard or read.
PO 1. Alphabetize a series of words to the first letter.
PO 1. Analyze the power, validity, and truthfulness of the arguments advanced in persuasive text.
PO 1. Consistently read grade level text with at least 90 percent accuracy.
PO 1. Read from a variety of genres with accuracy, automaticity (immediate recognition), and prosody (expression).
PO 1. Describe the historical and cultural aspects found in cross-cultural works of literature.
PO 1. Determine the author's specific purpose for writing the persuasive text.
PO 1. Predict text content using prior knowledge and text features (e.g., illustrations, titles, topic sentences, key words).
PO 1. Identify the topic of expository text, heard or read.
PO 1. Generate a series of rhyming words, including consonant blends.
PO 1. Locate specific information from functional text (e.g., letters, memos, directories, menus, schedules, pamphlets, search engines, signs, manuals, instructions, recipes, labels, forms).
PO 2. Determine whether a specific task is completed, by checking to make sure all the steps were followed in the right order, with picture cues to assist.
PO 2. Use context to determine the relevant meaning of a word.
PO 2. Distinguish between uppercase and lowercase letters.
PO 2. Sort familiar words into basic categories (e.g., colors, shapes, foods).
PO 2. Relate information and events in a reading selection to life experiences and life experiences to the text.
PO 2. Identify persuasive vocabulary (e.g., emotional words) used to influence readers' perspectives.
PO 2. Use knowledge of inflectional endings (e.g., -s, -ed, -ing) to identify base words.
PO 2. Derive meaning from books that are highly predictable, use repetitive syntax, and have linguistic redundancy.
PO 2. Orally segment a multi-syllable word into its syllables.
PO 2. Identify the meaning of metaphors based on literary allusions and conceits.
PO 2. Identify common structures and stylistic elements in literature, folklore, and myths from a variety of cultures.
PO 2. Evaluate the appropriateness of an author's word choice for an intended audience.
PO 2. Summarize the main idea and critical details of expository text, maintaining chronological or logical order.
PO 2. Generate clarifying questions in order to comprehend text.
PO 2. Hold a book right side up and turn pages in the correct direction.
PO 2. Identify the resolution of a problem or conflict in a plot.
PO 2. Recognize that a new word is created when a specific letter is changed, added, or removed.
PO 2. Identify the components (e.g., directions, legend, illustrations, diagram, sequence, bold face print, headings) of functional text.
PO 2. Distinguish among different kinds of evidence used to support conclusions (e.g., logical, empirical, anecdotal).
PO 2. Generate clarifying questions in order to comprehend text.
PO 2. Compare (and contrast) classic works of literature that deal with similar topics and problems (e.g., individual and society, meaning of friendship, freedom, responsibility).
PO 2. Interpret details from functional text for a specific purpose (e.g., to follow directions, to solve problems, to perform procedures, to answer questions).
PO 2. Identify signs, symbols, labels, and captions in the environment
PO 2. Distinguish fact from opinion in expository text.
PO 2. Restate facts from listening to expository text.
PO 2. Distinguish facts from opinions in expository selections such as editorials, newspaper articles, essays, reviews, and critiques, providing supporting evidence from the text.
PO 2. Identify the facts and details that support the author's argument regarding a particular idea, subject, concept, or object.
PO 2. Identify persuasive vocabulary (e.g., loaded/emotional words, exaggeration) used to influence readers' opinions.
PO 2. Orally produce rhyming words in response to spoken words (e.g., What rhymes with hat?)
PO 2. Confirm predictions about text for accuracy.
PO 1. Analyze how the patterns of organization, hierarchic structures, repetition of key ideas, syntax, and word choice influence the clarity and understandability of functional text.
PO 2. Classify common words into conceptual categories (e.g., animals, foods, toys).
PO 2. Read aloud with fluency in a manner that sounds like natural speech.

PO 2. Interpret figurative language, including, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, imagery, allusion, figures of speech, extended metaphor/conceit, and allegory with emphasis upon how the writer uses language to evoke readers' emotions.
PO 2. Evaluate the arguments an author uses in a document to refute opposing arguments and address reader concerns.
PO 2. Answer questions (e.g., who, what, where, when, why, how) about expository text, heard or read.
PO 2. Identify elements of a story, including characters, setting, and key events.
PO 2. Explain different elements of figurative language, including simile, metaphor, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, allusion, and imagery in a literary selection.
PO 2. Use context to identify the meaning of unfamiliar words (e.g., definition, example, restatement, synonym, contrast).
PO 2. Identify the theme in works of prose, poetry, and drama.
PO 2. Infer word meanings from context (e.g., definition, example, restatement, comparison/contrast, cause/effect).
PO 2. Confirm predictions about text for accuracy.
PO 2. Relate literary works to the traditions, themes, and issues of their eras.
PO 2. Synthesize information from multiple sources (e.g., texts, maps, illustrations, workplace documents, and schematic diagrams) to draw conclusions.
PO 2. Describe characters (e.g., traits, roles, similarities) within a literary selection, heard or read.
PO 3. Identify the words that comprise contractions (e.g., can't = can not, it's = it is, aren't = are not).
PO 3. Identify the objective(s) of functional text (e.g., warranties, product information, technical manuals, consumer publications, workplace documents).
PO 3. Identify organizational features (e.g., title, table of contents, heading, bold print) of expository text.
PO 3. Recognize the new spoken word when a specified phoneme is added, changed or removed (e.g., change cow to how, pan to an).
PO 3. Orally produce groups of words that begin with the same initial sound (alliteration).
PO 2. Evaluate the logic within functional text.
PO 3. Distinguish fact from opinion in expository text, providing supporting evidence from text.
PO 3. Describe familiar objects and events in both general and specific language.
PO 3. Recognize ways that forms of literature (including poetry, novel and/or short story) present similar themes differently across genres.
PO 3. Retell or re-enact a story, placing the events in the correct sequence.
PO 3. Analyze the way in which the theme or meaning of a selection represents a view or comment on life, providing textual evidence for the identified theme.

PO 3. Identify unsupported inferences or fallacious reasoning (e.g., circular reasoning, false causality, over-generalization, over-simplification, self-contradiction) in the arguments advanced in persuasive text.
PO 3. State the meaning of specific signs (e.g., traffic, safety, warning signs).
PO 3. Say letter sounds represented by the single-lettered consonants and vowels.
PO 3. Recognize the distinguishing features of a sentence (e.g., capitalization, ending punctuation).
PO 3. Generate clarifying questions in order to comprehend text.
PO 2. Compare a prediction about an action or event to what actually occurred within a text.
PO 3. Identify the moral of literary selection (e.g., fables, folktales, fairytales, legends).
PO 3. Sequence a series of events in a literary selection, heard or read.
PO 3. Determine the difference between figurative language and literal language.

PO 3. Locate specific information by using organizational features (e.g., table of contents, headings, captions, bold print, italics, glossaries, indices, key/guide words, topic sentences, concluding sentences, end notes, footnotes, bibliographic references) of expository text. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 3. Interpret details from functional text for a specific purpose (e.g., to follow directions, to solve a problem, to perform a procedure, to answer questions).
PO 2. Read aloud with fluency in a manner that sounds like natural speech, demonstrating automaticity.
PO 3. Determine author's main purpose (e.g., to inform, to describe, to explain) for writing the expository text.
PO 1. Determine an author's position regarding a particular idea, subject, concept, or object, using supporting evidence from the text.
PO 3. Describe the motivations of major and minor characters.
PO 3. Use context to identify the intended meaning of words with multiple meanings (e.g., definition, example, restatement, or contrast).
PO 3. Use graphic organizers in order to clarify the meaning of the text.
PO 3. Distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words.
PO 3. Describe the intended effect of persuasive strategies and propaganda techniques (e.g., bandwagon, peer pressure, repetition, testimonial, transfer, loaded words) that an author uses.
PO 3. Analyze culturally or historically significant literary works of American literature that reflect our major literary periods and traditions.
PO 3. Generate clarifying questions in order to comprehend text.
PO 3. Compare (and contrast) works within a literary genre that deal with similar themes (e.g., compare short stories, novels, short stories, poems).
PO 3. Identify unsupported inferences or fallacious reasoning in arguments advanced in persuasive text.
PO 3. Use graphic organizers in order to clarify the meaning of the text.
PO 3. Make relevant inferences by synthesizing concepts and ideas from a single reading selection.
PO 3. Start at the top left of the printed page, track words from left to right, using return sweep, and move from the top to the bottom of the page.
PO 3. Use knowledge of base words to identify compound words.
PO 3. Respond appropriately to questions based on facts in expository text, heard or read.
PO 2. Evaluate the effectiveness of the facts used to support an author's argument regarding a particular idea, subject, concept or object.
PO 4. Use graphic organizers in order to clarify the meaning of the text.
PO 1. Follow a set of written multi-step directions.
PO 4. Identify different parts of a book (e.g., front cover, back cover, title page) and the information they provide.
PO 4. Connect information and events in text to experience and to related text and sources.
PO 4. Identify the meaning of metaphors based on common literary allusions.
PO 4. Distinguish between initial, medial, and final sounds in single-syllable words.
PO 1. Evaluate the merit of an argument, action, or policy by citing evidence offered in the material itself and by comparing the evidence with information available in other sources.
PO 4. Recognize that two words can make a compound word (e.g., sailboat, football, popcorn).
PO 4. Compare interactions among major characters and minor characters in literary text with emphasis upon how the plot is revealed through action or the dialog.
PO 4. Determine whether a literary selection, heard or read, is realistic or fantasy.
PO 4. Connect information and events in text to experience and to related text and sources.
PO 4. Determine whether a literary selection, that is heard, is realistic or fantasy.

PO 4. Compare (and contrast) readings on the same topic, by explaining how authors reach the same or different conclusions based upon differences in evidence, reasoning, assumptions, purposes, beliefs, or biases.
PO 2. Determine what information (e.g., steps in directions, legend, supplies needed, illustrations, diagram, sequence) is missing in functional text.
PO 2. Relate literary works and their authors to the seminal ideas of their eras.
PO 1. Identify the main idea in expository text.
PO 4. Identify the title, author, and table of contents of a book.
PO 4. Distinguish between major characters and minor characters.
PO 4. Explain the writer's use of irony, contradictions, paradoxes, incongruities, and ambiguities in a literary selection.
PO 2. Identify the intended effect of persuasive vocabulary (e.g., loaded/emotional words, exaggeration, euphemisms) that the author uses to influence readers' opinions.
PO 3. Analyze the effectiveness of functional text (e.g., warranties, product information, technical manuals, consumer publications, workplace documents) to achieve its stated purpose(s).

PO 4. Organize information from both primary and secondary sources by taking notes, outlining ideas, paraphrasing information; and by making charts, conceptual maps, learning logs and/or timelines. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 4. Identify figurative language, including similes, personification, and idioms.

PO 4. Locate specific information by using organizational features (e.g., table of contents, headings, captions, bold print, glossaries, indices, italics, key words, topic sentences, concluding sentences) of expository text. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 3. Ask relevant questions in order to comprehend text.
PO 4. Read words with common spelling patterns (e.g., -ite, -ill, -ate).
PO 4. Identify the author's stated or implied purpose(s) for writing expository text.
PO 4. Use graphic organizers in order to clarify the meaning of the text.
PO 4. Identify the narrative point of view (e.g., first person, third person, omniscient) in a literary selection.
PO 1. Describe the central argument and its elements (e.g., argument by cause and effect, analogy, authority, emotion, or logic) in persuasive text.
PO 4. Determine the meaning of figurative language, including similes, metaphors, personification, and idioms in prose and poetry.
PO 4. Blend two or three spoken syllables to say words
PO 3. Use punctuation, including commas, periods, and question marks to guide reading for fluency.
PO 5. Participate (e.g., clapping, chanting, choral reading) in the reading of poetry by responding to the rhyme and rhythm.
PO 5. Connect information and events in a text to experience and to related text and sources.
PO 5. Recognize high frequency words and irregular sight words.

PO 5. Identify the meanings, pronunciations, syllabication, synonyms, antonyms, parts of speech, and correct spellings by using resources such as general and specialized dictionaries, thesauri, or glossaries (and CD-ROM and the Internet when available).
PO 5. Connect information and events in text to experience and to related text and sources.

PO 5. Locate specific information by using organizational features (e.g., table of contents, headings, captions, bold print, italics, glossaries, indices, key/guide words, topic sentences, concluding sentences) of expository text. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 4. Relate information and events in a reading selection to life experiences and life experiences to the text.

PO 5. Apply knowledge of the organizational structures (e.g., chronological order, time-sequence order, cause and effect relationships, logical order, by classification, problem-solution) of text to aid comprehension.
PO 5. Distinguish between long and short vowel sounds in orally stated single-syllable words (bit/bite).
PO 2. Evaluate the effectiveness of an author's use of rhetorical devices in a persuasive argument.
PO 5. Describe a character's traits using textual evidence (e.g., dialogue, actions, narrations, illustrations).
PO 2. Locate facts in response to questions about expository text.
PO 3. Analyze culturally or historically significant literary works of British and world literature that reflect the major literary periods and traditions.
PO 5. Blend spoken simple onsets and rimes to form real words (e.g., onset |c| and rime |at| makes cat).

PO 1. Analyze the author's use of literary elements:
  • theme (moral, lesson, meaning, message, view or comment on life),
  • point of view (e.g., first vs. third, limited vs. omniscient),
  • characterization (qualities, motives, actions, thoughts, dialogue, development, interactions),
  • setting (time of day or year, historical period, place, situation), and
  • plot (exposition, major and minor conflicts, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution).
PO 5. Distinguish between printed letters and words.

PO 3. Interpret details from a variety of functional text (e.g., warranties, product information, technical manuals, instructional manuals, consumer safety publications) for a specific purpose (e.g., to follow directions, to solve problems, to perform procedures, to answer questions).
PO 2. Determine whether a specific task is completed, by checking to make sure all the steps were followed in the right order.
PO 5. Analyze the influence of setting (e.g., time of day or year, historical period, place, situation) on the problem and resolution.
PO 1. Critique the effectiveness of the organizational pattern (e.g., logic, focus, consistency, coherence, visual appeal) of expository text.
PO 1. Alphabetize a series of words to the second letter.
PO 4. Identify specific instances of bias in persuasive text.
PO 2. Read aloud from familiar prose and poetry with fluency and appropriate rhythm, pacing, intonation, and vocal patterns.

PO 5. Determine the meanings, pronunciations, syllabication, synonyms, antonyms, and parts of speech of words by using a variety of reference aids, including dictionaries, thesauri, and glossaries (and CD-ROM and Internet when available).

PO 5. Identify appropriate print and electronic reference sources (e.g., encyclopedia, atlas, almanac, dictionary, thesaurus, periodical, textbooks, CD-ROM, website) needed for a specific purpose. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 5. Interpret graphic sources of information (e.g., charts, maps, diagrams, illustrations, tables, timelines, graphs) to support ideas. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 5. Analyze an author's development of time and sequence through the use of complex literary devices such as foreshadowing and flashbacks.
PO 3. Identify the intended effect of persuasive strategies (e.g., peer pressure, bandwagon, repetition) that the author uses to influence readers' perspectives.

PO 5. Identify the meanings, pronunciations, syllabication, synonyms, antonyms, and parts of speech of words, by using a variety of reference aids, including dictionaries, thesauri, and glossaries (and CD-ROM and the Internet when available).
PO 1. Identify simple prefixes (e.g., un-, re-) to determine the meaning of words.

PO 5. Apply knowledge of the organizational structures (e.g., chronological order, time-sequence order, cause and effect relationships, logical order, classification schemes, problem-solution) of text to aid comprehension.
PO 2. Describe how persuasive techniques (e.g., repetition, sentence variety, understatement, overstatement) contribute to the power of persuasive text.
PO 6. Interpret information from graphic features (e.g., charts, maps, diagrams, illustrations, tables, timelines) in expository text. <u>(Connected to Research Strand in Writing)</u>
PO 6. Identify the speaker or narrator in a literary selection.
PO 3. Determine how the meaning of the text is affected by the writer's word choice (e.g., literal vs. figurative language, idioms, adages).

PO 6. Explain how meaning is enhanced through various features of poetry, including sound (e.g., rhythm, repetition, alliteration, consonance, assonance), structure (e.g., meter, rhyme scheme), graphic elements (e.g., line length, punctuation, word position).
PO 2. Use knowledge of simple prefixes (e.g., un-, re-) to determine the meaning of words.
PO 1. Predict events and actions, based upon prior knowledge and text features.
PO 6. Identify antonyms, synonyms, and homographs for given words within text.
PO 6. Read common contractions fluently (e.g., I'm, I'll, can't).
PO 2. Analyze the author's use of figurative language, including simile, metaphor, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, allusion, and imagery in a literary selection.
PO 2. Recognize the distinguishing features of a sentence (e.g., capitalization of the first word, internal punctuation, ending punctuation, quotation marks).

PO 2. Determine the accuracy and truthfulness of one source of information by examining evidence offered in the material itself and by referencing and comparing the evidence with information available from multiple sources.
PO 6. Recognize that spoken words are represented in written language by specific sequences of letters.
PO 2. Determine what information (e.g., steps in directions, legend, supplies needed, illustrations, diagram, sequence) is extraneous in functional text.
PO 1. Describe literary elements of text including characters, plot (specific events, problem and solution), and setting.

PO 3. Apply knowledge of the following common spelling patterns to read words:
  • that drop the final e and add endings such as: -ing, -ed, or -able (e.g., use/using/used/usable)
  • with final consonants that need to be doubled when adding an ending (e.g., hop/hopping)
  • that require changing the final y to i (e.g., baby/babies)
  • that end in -tion, -sion, (e.g., election, vision)
  • with complex word families (e.g., -ight, -ought); and
  • that include common prefixes, suffixes and root words.
